ps - Macarons are $1.50.
author: Ruby H.

description: macarons are so good here. i was not able to try anything else but this small shop at the market is so cute i wish i had bought more things to try :).
author: Paumela B.

description:
I don't understand the whole cupcake craze that's going on. I mean, they all look great in the display case, but the taste always leaves something to be desired. The cupcakes are usually dry and bland and a complete disappointment. (Magnolia Bakery in NYC is the most famous and notorious offender.)

I approached the Miette display case, hoping not get duped yet again. Cupcakes offerings were basic (vanilla, chocolate or yellow cake) with different frosting flavors. I got a yellow cake with chocolate butter cream and Sooj got a chocolate cake with strawberry butter cream.

Yellow cake was a bit dry, but still tasted good, and the chocolate butter cream was incredible. It was almost as good as the mocha butter cream frosting Goldilocks uses on their mocha chiffon cakes. Sooj's chocolate cupcake was moist and chocolatey, and the strawberry butter cream frosting was really good. 

I also picked up a chocolate tart for my wife because she would have killed me if I didn't bring anything home for her. It was amazing. Rich, thick dark chocolate in a light, flaky shell was a nice contrast in textures and was absolutely delicious.

So good going, Miette. You gave me a little hope that the cupcake craze isn't a complete farce, and your other offerings also look great. Next time, I'm going to try some of the macarons.
author: Arnold G.

description:
Miette.... omg, I'm sure the M in their name stands for Madeleines. 

why? because their madeleines are THEE best I've ever had. soft, fluffy, buttery and lightly sweetened to perfection.  I savoured every bite and didn't want it to ever, ever end. its the ultimate baked goods heaven.

their cupcakes are pretty good too, but damn everything is so expensive! I guess the cutesy boxes, ribbons and everything is worth it :)
author: Jennie L.

description: I haven't had anything except the macarons but it was quite a tasty bite. The cupcakes looked really good as well and the staff seemed friendly while we mulled over our choices. I would definitely stop by here again, especially for the macarons.
author: Amy J.

description: Adorable store. I loved the decoration, everything had a good presentation. I had the gingerbread cupcake which was very moist, and the cream cheese frosting was not too sweet, very good. Pistachio macaroon was great. The cheesecake was alright. I'll definitely go back there.
author: Anelisa L.

description:
After lunch at One Market, I wandered here to get treats for the office. 

Great decision. I bought a variety of items and at least one of each of the cupcakes available.

Every Bite Is Perfection ... simple, dainty, elegant and wonderful! 

I purchased the lavender shortbread cookies here on my first visit many moons ago, and I have been a big fan ever since. People keep having birthdays ... and a little sweet something is better than nothing.

No line on this recent visit made my experience even better. It is all in the timing.
author: Lee R.

description: I tried the pistachio and chocolate lavender macaroons. To be fair, I'm not a macaroon connoisseur. I don't have much to compared them to, but I thought these were so-so. The lavender added a subtle, yet pleasant layer to the chocolate macaroon. However, I still liked the pistachio macaroon more. The filling for the chocolate was also a bit too dense for my taste.
author: C K.

description:
The staff at Miette were extremely resourceful, creative and wonderful.........they helped to create a hearty version of their " Princess cake"  that would stand up through two days of travel and the test of time to hold up for a photo shoot.They made the inside with butter cream instead and it held its perfect shape and survived a multitude of situations! 

I will go back for the cutesy powder pink heart-shaped Valentine's version of their princess cake this weekend!
author: Lee M.

description: I swear the macaroons jizz in your mouth when you bite into it.....everything here is super sweet. Get the pistache.
author: Diane L.

description:
My review is not on the macaroons, which of course I have tried and like.  

My review is on their own brand of chocolate.  I got 4 bars at $6 each.  I do not think they are worth $6. 

I will rank my 4 bars by my liking:

1) Lavender with sea salt with milk chocolate.  strong lavender flavor and the sea salt was a plus.

2) Fleur de Sel, which is just sea salt.  Nothing special, just the salt enhanced the chocolate flavor.

3) Jasmin, which is just flavored with jasmine flavor.  Not enough jasmine flavor at all.  Have to really play around in on the tongue to taste it.  Otherwise you are just tasting the chocolate.

4) red peppercorn with dark chocolate.  Cannot taste the red peppercorn at all.  the dark chocolate basically masked all the taste.  Maybe they should have more peppercorn...

the chocolate itself was ok... not too sweet... smooth...  but again for $6 each, and they are rather small...  not really worth it.
author: Janet S.

description:
Ok - so i spent a pretty penny on a variety of tarts, cakes, and macaroons. First off. Overly hyped. This place is fine and the Scharffenburger Chocolate domes are ever so pretty to look at, but they aren't nearly as tasty as they look. The macaroons were a good chewy consistency, but almost all the flavors were indistinguishable from the next and at $1.50 a pop....hardly worth the dinero. The one flavor that was especially strong was the Rose Geranium, which tasted like I bit into a bar of soap. Ick. Wasn't a fan. Of them all, hazelnut was the best. 
Overall, its a pretty product and comes across as a great gift, but I'd save my dollars and head next door for some gelato.
author: Stacy T.

description:
OK..so $2 is a bit pricey for a macaroon but the pistachio is deliciously amazing...hazelnut too (the lavendar is kinda weird)...with your blue bottle cafe americano :p..

Their lemon shortbreads and lemon tarts are also delicious (walnut shortbread wasn't my fave..kinda oily).
author: Jenny L.

description:
Two Words: Pistachio Macarons. 

Thank You Lan for introducing me to one of the yummiest cookies in the world! 

You should buy one for yourself and one for a friend. Spread the love!
author: Jennifer T.

description: Two words . . . French macarons. Not the coconut creations, but a heavenly concoction comprised of two delicate cookies bonded with a rich, creamy filling, then lightly glazed. Usually available in chocolate, vanilla, pistachio, hazelnut, grapefruit, and - best of all - chocolate-Mandarin orange. No more than a mouthful, they're outrageously priced, but on those occasions when you want to reward yourself or need to lift your sagging spirits, these are the treats that will do the trick.
author: Gourmet G.

description: All the macaroons were the best I've had... hazelnut was the best. Also the ice cream sandwich was unbelievlible too. And this is researched info folks...3 trips in 5 days to the Ferry builiding and this place.
author: Clint M.

description: $7 for a tiny lemon tart....omg.....never again....I'll make them myself!
author: Vicky R.

description:
After overstuffing ourselves at Hog Island today, we wanted dessert.  We  originally wanted a gelato, but since we saw this place first, decided to give it a try.

We fell in line and when it was our turn, the woman on the straight, long-ish dark haired snotty woman at the counter decided to make believe that she's blind and somehow didn't see us and decided to ask the gentleman who literally just walked up the counter if he needed any help.  Thankfully, he said we were there first, so she had no choice but to ask us what we wanted.  

I ordered 2 each of the macarons.  There were maybe 6-7 varieties, strangely enough, all were either a sickly, speckled beige color, and 2 in chocolate.  They were completely different flavors, but I guess they had no strength to put food coloring on any of those bad boys so if you ordered a bunch like we did, you'd pretty much have to play Russian Roulette and gain a bunch of unwanted pounds eating each one until you hit upon the flavor you wanted in the first place.  Brilliant!

Next, my sister wanted a pot de creme.  The same woman decided to correct her in the proper way of saying it.  Well, my sister happened to have spent several summers throughout France, painting, and she certainly knows how it's proper pronunciation, but just didn't want to be pretentious and rub it in.  I guess since this woman's big pursuit in life is to wait a counter at the Ferry Building, she feels its her very own crusade to teach the populace in general proper pronunciation.

She did a bunch more things that are just too annoying to describe.  My point is, if you decide to buy anything from this place, pray you don't get her to serve you.

Would you believe she still f-ed up and gave my sister the wrong dessert after all that crap she gave us?  We discovered this in the car, far away from the building already. but since the garbage she was trying to pawn off on us was too sickly looking, I told my sister to go back and get what she ordered in the first place, in stead of what was given, about 1/4 the price of what we paid.  Convenient mistake, huh?

The macarons tasted absolutely disgusting, stale and much too "processed".  All this, close to $30 + a whole bunch of unnecessary stresss = priceless.

I'LL NEVER GO BACK.  AVOID AT ALL COST!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Rhodora M.

description: May 17th was the first time I've been inside the Ferry Building. I was like a kid in a candy store! I first made my rounds by checking out each store to see what they had to offer. Miette stuck out to me not only for their pink sign but the goodies behind the glass case. On my way back around, I noticed the macaroons and cupcakes. Considering I've never had a macaroon before I decided to make my one purchase at the Ferry Building a selection of their macaroons. These tiny cookies were better than I imagined. These delicate things were not only light and airy but full of flavor. Out of their selection I think my favorite is the vanilla. I'd definitely be back for more macaroons and possibly a cake purchase. One negative I didn't expect was the price, $1.75 for one little cookie but I guess the flavor makes up for the cost.
author: Angela S.

description: This is my all time favorite bakery. Their gingersnaps, graham crackers, macarons, etc, etc, are to die for. I typically spend a small fortune whenever I go, but well worth the money. Most highly recommend!!!
author: Felice A.

description: Not as good as the one in Oakland! Every time I go here they are out of my favorite french macaroon which are vanilla macaroons they are out consistently every time i go and they have less pastries than the Oakland location. I am not giving this place 5 stars because every time they are sold out this sucks. Anyway if you go get an ice cream sandwich with creme fraiche or my favorite vanilla macaroons if they haven't sold out.
author: Desiree L.

description:
I am seriously SO over cupcakes. They are so overplayed. Sicky sweet and gross..meh. I'm ready for some fruit. 

Yeah right!!!! I think maybe I can talk myself back into fruit but then I bake a dreamy batch of double vanilla cuppies...ORr find myself steamrolling through random people in the Ferry Building making a beeline for Miette Patisserie the minute I heard it was located nearby.

And cold, hard reality intrudes. Next thing you know, I'm pointing and ordering, and handing over the credit card. Clutching my pink and white bag with sweaty hands. And still thinking, yeah I know I just bought a 'few to sample'....but it's no big deal.

Even as I sit here writing this review, dark chocolate crumbs and creamy chocolate buttercream frosting are smeared all over my cheap paper-towel-excuse-for-a-napkin. Yeah over them...more like ALL over them like white on rice.

By the way...the Miette cupcakes are simply amazing...soft, cakey and crumbly with the most divine creamy buttercream frosting. Def one of my favorites thus far. And I've only had the chocolate with chocolate buttercream. The other two MIGHT make it to tomorrow, purely out of sheer exhaustion on the taster's part.
author: Mara T.

description:
Background: The Principal Investigator's current body of work has found that cupcakes, while perceived by many to be overrated (salty b & Arnold G, 2007), can in fact induce positive affective states in consumers. The affective states most commonly associated with cupcake consumption is euphoria, with anecdotal evidence suggesting what some describe as "warm and fuzzies" (Steph P., 2007). Most recently, the PI launched a multi-site, ongoing research project  in San Francisco http://www.yelp.com/biz/oHuPyoGY7nhCQeprHCv21g?hrid=z3tvKVFONgQSedr7hkj57A to test levels of euphoria induced and gather evidence for the question of "Who has the best cupcakes in the Bay Area?".  The current review presents another study in this research project.

Method:

The site for Study #2: Miette Patisserie in the Ferry Building Marketplace. Samples included:

1) Chocolate cupcake with vanilla buttercream frosting
2) Gingerbread cupcake with cream cheese frosting
3) Chocolate cupcake with rapsberry buttercream frosting
4) Assortment of macarons: hazelnut, pistachio, chocolate lavender

Results:

Again, we use the same dependent variable of Steph's level of euphoria (where 1 = I would rather eat dirt, and 10 = I could die right now and not give a crap):

1) Chocolate cupcake with vanilla buttercream frosting: The cake is bittersweet chocolate (slightly on the dense and dry side) and topped with a soft kiss of vanilla butter cream frosting. Really - the frosting is like *eating* kisses. The kind that makes you want to go back over and over, dreaming of the soft and warm and velvety touch passing across your lips. Is this how buttercream is supposed to taste like? I have never tasted and experienced buttercream quite like this. That imagery stuck with me as I slowly savored this small-sized cupcake. Warm and fuzzies in full effect. DV = 9

2) Gingerbread with cream cheese frosting: Also small and on the dense side. The taste of molasses and cloves is quite strong, even for gingerbread flavor. A surprisingly light cream cheese frosting provides nice balance to the sweet cake. I don't think I would have this again, but there are probably others who would experience more euphoria with this. DV = 7

3) Chocolate with raspberry frosting: Very similar to the chocolate cupcake though I found this moister on this particular day. The frosting is just as light and kiss-like, with a smooth pink hue and strong raspberry flavor. I enjoyed Noe Valley Bakery's take on raspberry frosting more, with its flecks of raspberry preserves. Still, a solid cupcake. DV = 8

4) Macarons: Not to be confused with macaroons (which are made with coconut flakes), macarons are traditional French pastries made with egg whites, ground almond flour and sugar. Various flavors of icings and spreads are spread between two little cookies. Miette features many different flavors, such as hazelnut, chocolate lavender, vanilla, strawberry, chocolate, pistachio, and rose vanilla).  They do these little tiny little indulgences ($1.50 each) very well.  When you bite into the 1.5-inch disc, you feel the tension between chewy and crunchy and a smooth nutty flavor combining with the potent flavor of the filling. I have tried these at Miette many times to try to assess reliability, and it seems that there are days when the macarons are fresher (and therefore more chewy than crunchy) than others. DV = 8

Discussion:

At about $3 for a small 2-inch cupcake, it seems that Miette's approach is to concentrate flavor into a more dense cupcake. Miette may suffer from the greater likelihood of a less moist cupcake with the smaller size. I personally find the flavors of the cake and the frosting to be good enough to make repeat visits to Miette potentially beneficial to my overall mental health. This little patisserie, fortunately, offers many other choices if cupcakes are not for you. The macarons seem to induce feelings of euphoria. With the many choices available for cupcake and macaron flavors, in addition to other offerings such as tartes, cookies, panna cotta and pudding, it would be reasonable to suggest that there is something for everybody. While their cupcakes may not be the best of the Bay, the evidence points to a happier post-Miette Steph.
author: Steph P.

description:
Sticks of butter used to be my favorite thing as a kid. Seriously. My mom would have to keep me away from eating sticks of butter. I know butter. 

The chocolate frosting on my cupcake tasted like butter. Not butter cream frosting, butter. 

Stick to the French macaroons.
author: Michelle B.

description:
I love this little shop! It's great they're open later on a Saturday too. Everything else in the ferry building was shutting their doors as we walked in shortly after 7p - but Miette & Blue Bottle welcomed us with open cash registers. 

I picked up my fave - lavender shortbread - and a treat for the boat ride back to Marin - a gingerbread cupcake. It was great! Sorry someone else had a not so good experience with theirs, but mine was the perfect 3 bites to my cappuccino from Blue Bottle. 

They had some great little stocking stuffers that my friends stocked up on too - good to know for next year :)
author: Liz K.

description:
Apparently I am have become a the Goldilocks of cupcakes (and not just fro-yo), because I haven't found the right one yet...

But my search for great cupcakes has reminded me that I work just across the way from the Ferry Bldg, and that this building houses an ever-so-cute bakery by the name of Miette.  I made the short trip over this past Fri. in hopes of finally finding a cupcake that would satiate my craving.  Well.  I did find cupcakes but they weren't entirely to my liking (yet again).   The frosting was much, I repeat much better than the stuff Kara's pawned off on me last weekend, but the cake itself is was not as moist as I'd hoped, but I'd heard this about their cupcakes before.  I did however, find the chocolate one to be really moist.  So all in all they were pretty good, just limited in flavors.

But whatever they lack in certain things, they make up for in others, such as the French macaroons, and the shortbread.  One word, YUM!  I only tried the pistachio macaroons and the lavender shortbread.  Scary thing is that I woke up this morning, picked up the book I was reading when I fell asleep last night, looked to my nightstand and picked up the Miette bag and proceeded to eat some more of the lavender shortbread cookies.

Bad habits I know...I didn't need to gain 5 extra pounds in 2 days right...

I'll definitely be back!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I wrote a haiku for Miette:

I got a cupcake
it was lovely vision
ashy Larry dry

Eh, they can't all be gems.

The cake was super dry and I didn't even finish it.

This would be a one star review, but I didn't try anything else and it doesn't seem quite fair.  
Everything LOOKS beautiful and you do eat with your eyes first, but unfortunately for Miette, the mouth is second in line.   
Followed by the lap, and then shamefully back to the mouth.

Ps
anyone who gave this "funny" points should die on their birthday.
author: Boiled H.

description:
Came here a couple of weeks ago to get some sweets and ofcourse raved about it on the way. BUT. the prices on some of the items went up (as if it was not expensive enough) higher than i will pay and the items seem smaller, and did not seem as fresh..  I will not return as much as I did. 
  Oh and the staff, smile alittle bit !!
author: Jack O.

description: In my opinion, it's pretty average.  I have  had their macarons and their cupcakes.  meh, I've had better.  It is over priced ....anything in the Ferry Building is over priced.  Not worth it.
author: Cj P.

description:
Sometimes I wonder if this place is popular because of its location and the aura that 'eating at the Ferry Building' has.. (kind of like 'going to Whole Foods')  The one cupcake I had there was "okay"- sugary sweet with just a hint of vanilla.. or was it almond essence?  The teeny weeny bag o'butter cookies that my friend bought was $5!!!! (FIVE dollars? For 3 ounces of cookies- come on.. if you have organic butter and a bowl and some organic flour at home, you can do this...)

I mean, the presentation is just ah-dorable and the cake stands that they sell would do Martha Stewart Proud, but I'm not totally sold on this place. Yet.

*********************
Update 12/27/06: Someone PM'ed me with the subject 'cookies' today, perhaps to explain why the butter cookies cost $5... (Sorry, didn't read it... to prevent my blood pressure from increasing any more than it already is, I have vowed to delete such PMs)
author: M'ia K.

description:
I am still dreaming of the Rose Geranium Macaron... Gluten-free and heavenly. mmm... 

I also had the Orange Chocolate Macaron, which was also delicious, but the Rose Geranium was delicate, flavorful, and special.

The price $1.75 for a macaron is a little steep, but I was willing to splurge (and I probably will again!)
author: Deirdre P.

description: OMG Macarons. Tasty, delicious, light and yet still crisp macarons. I only got the rose geranium one and it was so good. The flavour was light and tasty. I can't wait to go back and get a box worth of macarons now.
author: Shauna S.

description:
As a pastry chef, I have often lamented about the utter lack of decent, Euro-style bakeries here in this lovely city, but Miette Organic Patisserie is by far the best I've seen in quite a while.

Located in the Ferry Plaza, a quiet, simple elegance envelops you as you gaze around the shop at the cutesy pink, sage green and chocolate brown accents, the mouth-watering cakes and pastries that are quite simple but meticulously finished; no intimidating, overdone perfect sculptures of icing and garish colors.  Everything in the shop looks like you could actually make it yourself, eat and enjoy it.

And enjoy it you will.  Lovely seasonal fruit tartlets with clear, fresh flavors, mini scones, classic chocolate eclairs and homey cakes enrobed with Scharffenberger chocolate and fresh buttercreams with clever names like, Debutante, Bumblebee and Tomboy are sure to get your attention.  For small appetites, try the chocolate cupcakes topped with a dollop of perfect swirled buttercream, very light, with just the right amount of sweetness.

The french style macaroons are not to be missed, any pastry chef out there knows how difficult it is to get these airy confections just right, and the bakers at Miette have cracked it.  These wonderful almond cookies in flavors like classic chocolate, chocolate mandarin, coffee and others are the best outside Paris' famed Laduree, a world renown tea shop revered for their macaroons.  With the right amount of tender chewiness, and smooth buttercreams in the center, these cookies perfect for indulgent snacking, hostess gifts, tea parties or even wedding favors.

My favorite is the Chocolate Cream Cake, a very decadent slice of rich, silky chocolate ganache covered chocolate cake layered with a very light vanilla cream with crunchy cocoa nibs folded into it.  At $5.00 a slice, it is perfect to share as it is so rich with a cup of tea or a glass of Pinot Noir.  

Drop by Miette, next time you want or need dessert for any occasion
author: Candace W.

description: This place is soo good! Those macaroon cookies are to die for, but everything is great here.  Whenever I come to the ferry building this is a must visit, along with some blue bottle coffee makes for a great treat.  Psst.  they are super close to eachother too! :)
author: Loretta M.

description:
High overhead translates into pricey product. Product price influenced by overhead not ingredients. Pickin' up what I'm puttin' down? 

Now don't get me wrong, Miette is a quaint place in the Ferry building and many of their items I find very delicious but for the price, I don't think they equal out. 

Here's a quick overview of menu items that explode goodness in your mouth: 

Bumblebee - The menu says it's America's standard for birthdays. I don't know if that's true but the yellow cake is moist, sweet and delicious. The chocolate icing is like sweet velvet or silk melting in your mouth. The cake and frosting compliment each other perfectly, yet taste muy bueno individually. This cake rivals the cake that Ms. Jenkins' makes for Sunday's after service meal. 

Scharffen Berger - Wow! This cake has one of those fancy fancy tastes that my ghetto palate doesn't quite know what to make of it. That taste is called mmm mmm good. This cake has bittersweet, truffle ganache but I can't tell where the frosting stops and where the cake starts. Yummo! 

Old-fashioned - Whuuuut? Chocolate cake with Italian meringue and again a moist, soft and sweet treat that you can eat with a spoon. 

These are the items I've had and enjoyed, others I don't feel are worth mentioning. 

I am usually the person designated to go out and get birthday treats, so I've tried many items from Miette. The money from the fund goes further if we purchase cakes as opposed to cupcakes, hence the opening comment.
author: ARSON P.

description:
I am a macaroon person.  I love them.  

Miette has the best macaroons in the city hands down and, I'm not just saying that because I like the design and logo on their bags (for those of you who know I love design).  If the macaroons at Miette were not the best, no amount of cool packaging and fabulous design could get me to proclaim they are ze best.  I promise.  

Oh yes, the cupcakes. . .my friend and his family love the cupcakes.  I even think his sister will break her diet for a cupcake.  They rave about the gingerbread cupcake with cream cheese frosting as well as the chocolate cupcake.  I on the other hand will break my "off-the-crack" (aka no sugar) rule for one of their insanely good brownies, lemon/pink grapefruit/pistachio macaroons, or a sea salt caramel.  

Ah heaven. . .
author: James M.

description:
Made this my last stop on my way out from the Ferry Building farmer's market. Was going to a friend's house for a grilled steak and raw oyster fest and wanted to bring something decadent, sweet... and pretty. Decided to posh it up and get an assortment from Miette. Ended up getting 6 cupcakes and 2 tarts for $30. I didn't get to try everything I brought but did try:

Chocolate cupcake with vanilla cream frosting - so classic, so moist, so yum!
carrot cake cupcake - cupcake was a bit dry but the frosting was good. I enjoy a good carrotcake, but not a huge fan of coconut, which this had. 
lemon tart - OMG! I'm getting that one AGAIN
key lime tart - good key lime and crust, but not a fan of the marshmallow meringue. a bit too cloying for me

Did I mention pretty?
author: tessie n.

description:
I love french pastries, while we we're in the Pier 1 Marketplace I had to try this place. 

Had the macaroons and some other small things. 

Everything was great. friendly service but the store front was a little small. 

When I'm back in the city I will be back to try more things.
author: Eric H.

description:
Just forget it Citizen Cupcake, if that is your real name. Magnolia in Greenwich Village? Only good for New Yorkers who are used to paying for style over substance.

If I decide to get fat (and I just might - I've done it before) it will be in large part to their gingerbread cupcakes switching off to the grapefruit macaroons in season. Yes, grapefruit macaroons. You so haven't lived yet.
author: patrick g.

description: OMG how did I not know about this place?! I come to the city often because my brother lives there and also because SF is one my favorite cities in the US and I love finding new dessert spots! I have no idea how I did not know about this gem but OH EM GEE am I stoked I tried it. Two words- GINGERBREAD CUPCAKE. This baby was voted top cupcake by food network in the world- YES THE WORLD! I just had to try this with those kinds of claims! The reviews do not lie, this cupcake is AMAZING. The cake is dense but not too overwhelming and the frosting is perfect. The flavor will blow your mind! It is a must try and in fact go out of your way to come here and try this cupcake! YUM! I also tried the vanilla ice cream sandwich and the macarons. The ice cream sandwich was okay, nothing to write home about and being a BIG macaron person I thought they were above average. The cookie is delicate and moist (yes I said the M word) but the cream is a lil too creamy for me. The rose was my favorite of the three I tried. Next time I come into the city I would like to try the gingersnap cookies as they have also been added to the top 100 foods before you die to try list.
author: Autumn Y.

description: I have only tried their macarons here, and they are great! Super thin exterior shell. Soft, chewy underlying layer that is like an extremely moist brownie. The chocolate macaron has a relatively pronounced chocolate flavor mixed with a coconut-y aftertaste. Great texture, taste, size, and price.
author: Catherine N.

description:
pricey pastries...for a pretty penny.....patience present.....for pitter-patter 'n' pause....people proceed.....patrons ponder.....over petite pastries......pastries pleasing?....

located in the inners of 1 ferry building....tourists roam....lines form...patrons eager to sample..many choices....while miette cakes offers everything that is pretty, petite 'n' polished....cupcakes 'n' pastries their angle.....location not ideal for locals...
author: Hen A.

description:
Everything is beautiful to look at. Really, really beautiful. Unfortunately, beauty isn't everything! My cupcake was way too dense,  bland and boring. I am a frosting fiend and this stuff was a real disappointment. Too buttery. Almost tasteless. 

My husband (lover of all things chocolate) went with your basic nut-less brownie. He was not impressed. That's when I really knew Miette was overrated. 

Do yourself a favor and head to Delessio on Market and Gough for some delicious sweet treats. Sorry, Miette, you just didn't do it for me.
author: Abby W.

description:
Miette is the place that makes me want to get out of my house in my Pink Juicy Couture sweats and stroll down to Ferry Building with strong coffee on my hand.  I just love this Patisserie.  So French, so decadent.  Nothing is overly sweet which I hate.

Old Fashioned cupcake is so moist, it falls apart.  Not in dry flaky way, but as soon as you have first bite, it just reveals rich and dewy inside.  Macaron is $1.50 each, and it is really good.  Strawberry and geranium is my favorite flavor.  I had this for the first time in Paris, and Miette's macaron is as stellar.  It has creamy filling, but cookies make it chewy.  I haven't seen anyone who didn't like it so far.  Carmel Pot de Creme is another one I always get.  It comes in a glass pot with Miette engraved, and you can use it later for candle holder. Gift wrap is also tres chic.
author: Jooyeon H.

description: A little treat from Miette is the perfect way to cap off a 4505 burger!
author: Robert M.

description:
Eating a huge brunch at Universal Cafe didn't stop me from craving something sweet. I decided that it would be "Let's only go to places I've never been to before but always wanted to" Day. I know you must all be thinking that I can't consider myself a true confectionery lover because I have never indulged in Miette Cakes before. It's not that I haven't tried to get my hands on their goodies. For some reason, they're always closed when I'm at the Ferry Building. I always believed it was some conspiracy against me. 

Anyways, even though we had just finished a hearty brunch, I needed my sweet fix and on this adventurous and spontaneous day, we headed over to Miette. We parked on the street across from the Ferry Building, and even on a Sunday, we were limited to 7.5 minutes per $0.25. We fed the meter $1.00 and had 30 minutes to run in and out of there. 

We headed towards the pink sign and when we arrived in front of the case of perfect sweet creations, it was like a choir of angels were greeting me. Everything looked incredibly tooth-achingly delectable, but I restrained myself and choose only 2 treats: an adorable chocolate pot de creme (in a cute keepsake glass pot with Miette inscribed on it, which you can recycle back for $1 -- I kept mine of course) and a chocolate cupcake with buttercream frosting. Raoul also got a chocolate macaroon, and as we were on a time crunch, we fled over to the seating area next to Peet's to scarf down our chocolate goodies. After inhaling my yummy pot de creme and cupcake, I was truly in heaven.
author: Connie C.

description: The macaroons!! They are awesome but at 1.85 a piece, i can only buy them for special occasions. Other pastries look delicious but I haven't tried too many of them.
author: Maya N.

description:
Dear Miette-

You are totally cute and my friends love you. You're killin it with presentation and adorable-ness. So good job there. Ahem. Would you mind making at least one vegan cupcake/pastry/baked good, even just one day of the week? Here is an example of what would be great: Saint Cupcake (in Portland, OR) offers a great variety of beautiful cupcakes in a stupidly-cute environment (and don't even get me started on Sweetpea bakery in PDX...gahh) and while the majority of the cupcakes at Saint Cupcake contain all kindsa' dairy&eggs they still offer at least 2-3 types of delicious! vegan cupcakes on a daily basis. I'm just sayin....

xo

-Sara who-really-likes-vegan-cupcakes-and-works-a-block-away-from-the-ferry-building-winkwinknudgenudge
author: M M.

description:
So, I'd been thinking of having a quiet week with most of the food events relegated to the weekend.  However, I got an email from Arnold G.:
"Pastrami and Cupcake."

And I groaned and knew that my food eating would likely intensify two-fold, but I couldn't resist because food-events with Arnold are always lots of fun.  

During our pastrami sandwich, we discussed in depth what can go wrong with cupcakes.  We agreed that the biggest problem is dryness: leave a cupcake out too long and it's stale, dry, and just unpalatable.  One can combat the problem by putting in oil, but that's just a shortcut that also cuts down on the buttery richness of cakes. So, bakeries are working against the nature of small individual cakes exposed to the air and elements.  The big plus of cupcakes can be a better ratio of frosting to cake than is offered in a traditional cake.

So after our pastrami sandwich, we went to Miette, eyed their cupcakes and decided on two different flavors, one vanilla with chocolate buttercream and chocolate with strawberry buttercream.  They had the cutest confectionary flowers, one each, on top of the frosting.

Miette's cupcakes are $3, and worth every cent during lunchtime.  Moist, rich, and the butter cream frosting was decadent without having the hardness that I associate with butter frostings.  I feel that their buttercream frosting is probably either made with cream or a mix of butter and cream...it's certainly not the hard butter frosting that other places have and which makes the cupcake all wrong.

So, into the future a day, two other food events later: Steph shows up with a box of Miette macarons.  She's so sweet: she got the strawberry one specially for me.  Delicious, crumbly, and not too sweet.  A perfect cookie.  

I am coming back more often.  Their chocolate pot de creme is $5...I figure it's a potential orgasm in a teeny cute glass pot.
author: Sooj O.

description:
the fiance and i decided to stop by miette to try the infamous macaroons. afterall, we are off to paris on wednesday so we need to start training our palatte for french fine dining and pastries :)

i loved the chocolate orange one and he loved the coffee one. 

5 minutes later we came back and bought a bag full of assorted flavors including pistachio, lemon, and vanilla. 

now we just have to compare them to the ones in paris (la duree).
author: Helen Y.

description:
Wonderful Rose and Pistachio Macaroons...Waited in a short line on a sunny Saturday morning for macaroons in the open pastry shop located in the Ferry Building.

The macaroons were on the larger side and very delicious... I might even venture to say they were the best I have had. The flavors availible were rose, chocolate orange, pitachio, chocolate, hazelnut, vanilla, etc.  Each macaroon was $1.75. The Miette glass case also held pastries and delicacies. 

FYI's~
* The shop has high priced nuts, mixes, and adorable knick knacks for sale in pastels
* You can purchase espresso
author: Natalie W.

description:
The macarons are excellent.  Very fresh with a perfect texture.  My favorite ones are the vanilla and the pistachio.  Also enjoyed one of the ice cream sandwiches.  The texture of the cookie was nice and crispy.

Looking forward to trying more things on the menu.
author: Tamara A.

description:
it is only right that miette be my first review...

miette, you are my one true bay -area-patisserie love.

i can't sing enough praises for miette. and believe me when i say i am a cupcake snob.

miette is a delight in san francisco. their adorable treats not only look amazing, they are sooooooo tasty! after visitng several times & trying out different treats, i ordered a vanilla tomboy birthday cake here and due to scheduling issues for the birthday celebration, i kept having to postpone the cake but the staff was sooo sweet about it all. i've since returned to order cakes and treats and pick some up for myself along the way, and have never once been disappointed. on top of perfection-known-as-pastries, they have always been extremely kind and friendly with me. i mean, that kind of customer service paired with top quality (organic!) product calls for praise. needless to say, i am constantly impressed --- i will continue to stay loyal and come back often. :)

i've tried about everything and still cant get enough! i highly reccomend you start by trying their old fashioned cupcake before anything else. then their scharffenberger cake, their unbelievably delicious banana cream tart, their mini scones & lavender shortbread cookies & macarons (pick up a handful to take home!), umm actually TRY EVERYTHING!! you won't be disappointed, promise. and even better, almost everything comes in either a personal size or a large size. so if you come to eat with friends, you can each order a personal size of something and share/taste it all, and whichever one you love the most, you can order for a birthday cake or something. and definitely make sure you get a glimpse of their loaves and carrot cakes, toooo adorable!

oh and can i just say, the food network totally missed out when they didn't declare miette #1 in the cupcake challenge!!! poor editing on the show as well!

again, let me highlight the extremely friendly staff (cannot emphasize this enough!), super cute decor (both for the patisserie & the treats), delicious treats that will keep you coming back for more!!!

in a perfect world, they would open a store in downtown SF (closer to my company's building haha...)  so i could come here allll the time.
author: Stella C.

description:
UPDATE: Several months later, I was craving cake so headed over to the Ferry Building for a cupcake. I was disappointed - it seems the quality has gone downhill. My cake was dry - maybe even stale.  Next time I am going to follow the suggestion of the Great Liz S and try un macaron!

ORIGINAL: Skipped dessert at Slanted Door to try one of these babies and did not regret the choice. Chocolate cupcake with vanilla buttercream frosting was great. Not quite heaven, but I think it would have to have nuts in it to reach that sainted position!
author: Lise L.

description:
I picked up their caramels today while I was at Farmer's Market.  I thought the store front was very cute looking and caught my eye.  Recently I have been on a hunt for some great sweets so I decided to browse around while I waited for my table at Hog Island...

There wasn't much to look out in the store.  The cases where the cakes and cupcakes were was crowded by people and it didn't seem that interesting.  They were tiny and overpriced.  I didn't feel like checking them out... maybe one day when I come on a non-Farmer's Market day I will give it a try.

After some pondering I decided to give the caramels a try because I need new places to Yelp and write about in my blog! ^_^ So why not.  They are only 50 cents a piece and they are a tiny tiny piece that resembles salt water taffy but you get a lot less.  They also sold taffy but no flavors that would make me want to try.  I actually really enjoyed the chocolate and salted caramel.  As for the tea flavored one... that was odd and I didn't like that.  

I still think that Boule in LA has a better salted caramel, but the ones here were not bad. They put the 3 tiny pieces in a cute lil bag and gave it to me.  I might give this place another go so I can fairly rate them on their cakes & stuff, but based on what I saw and tried... it's not bad but nothing I would crave or come back specifically for IMHO
author: Kat L.

description: I love coming here to get those hamburger looking cookies in all flavors. I get them for my fiancee every now and then and she claims they are the best in town. Guys - if you want to get your lady a small gift, get her a box of these cookies, she'll love them.
author: Huy T.

description:
1.5


Everything about the store is tres chic and cute.

The cupcakes are so pretty!!  For presentation, I'd give them 4 stars.

But people, I'm here to judge the taste and the cupcakes sure taste yucky.
author: Dorothy L.

description:
I had always admired the pretty cakes and tarts from here, but hadn't tried them until last weekend. I figured it would be the perfect thing to bring to a small party.

I asked the girl working there what she recommended and bought 4 different things, a chocolate torte, a small sharfenberger cake, the banana creme tort, and the lemon meringue. The banana creme & the lemon meringue were AMAZING, the chocolate ones were good too. At $5 a piece, not too terrible if you want to bring some classy desserts somewhere.

Today I went back and tried one of the mini chocolate orange scones, which are small but for $.75 VERY reasonable! Also the cupcakes are delicious too...usually cupcakes look way better than they taste, but these were excellent!

I want to try the Princess cake...so for my next b-day, I'd like one of those PLEASE! :)
author: Elaine S.

description: I just stop by this patisserie cause there were a plenty of fancy cupcakes and macaroons!! Looks so pretty and at the same time so cute!! Every girls who really like something fancy come to like it!! I tried macaroon( $1.5) it was so nice. It is different from sweets you buy in other sweet shop. if you wanna have something taste sophisticated, you should try it once!
author: Kozy T.

description:
I'd been reading and reading about this place, so when the opportunity presented itself to go to the Ferry Building, Miette was a required stop.  I opted to go for a blueberry tart, a slice of the chocolate cream cake, a chocolate macaroon, and a chocolate madeleine.  

I loved the tart--the custard was thick and rich and mildly flavored with vanilla--a perfect complement to the fresh blueberries, but what I appreciated the most was the tart pastry itself.  It had a great, not overly buttery flavor and even better yet, a great crumb--firm enough to support the custard, but tender enough to not require a steak knife to saw through.  Winner for sure.

The cream cake--not so much.  This will be a very unpopular comment, but I thought the cake tasted like a costco chocolate cake.  Costco chocolate cake happens to be pretty good--but this slice at Miette cost me about 1/4 of an entire sheet cake of costco.  The cream was good, but I also did not happen to like all the nibs riddled throughout the cake.  I don't mind a little crunch in my cake, for texture, but the amount of nibs was distracting and since it didn't add any additional flavor, I ended up spitting a lot of them out--luckily in the privacy of my own home.

Finally the madeleine and the macaron were decent.  I'm glad I stopped by--my curiosity is satiated, and to be really honest, I'm kinda glad I'm not in love.  My wallet would hate me forever and there are other goodies in the ferry building that can now get a little more love (from me).
author: Candace C.

description:
What is it about this girl that, on more than one occasion and in more than one city, will hike in excess of 50+ NYC blocks and a few miles in SF to get to a cupcakery?  Don't ask.  It's some sort of minor obsession ... And the hiking/walking allows for minimal guilt when indulging in the sugary perfection.  That's about as close to an answer as I got!?...

I carted a friend on a little excursion, each with our pups, down Embarcadero and into the Ferry Building.  "Must -- get -- cupcake."  We arrived!  They were out of the vanilla tasties but were left with some delish chocolate ones to choose from.  We selected the chocolate with coffee frosting and the old fashioned, chocolate with a meringue whipped frosting and candy coated peanut.  They were both YUMMY!!!  You could taste every bit of coffee in each and every bite of the first cupcake and the old fashioned .... pure chocolate bliss!  

While I haven't been able to find the simplicity of a Magnolia Bakery cupcake here in SF, this trip to Miette was worth it!
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
I'm not a huge pastry fan, but I do buy the cupcakes with an adorable similarity to a breast for my husband and those horny-boy types in my life.  $3 for a smile - I'll do it!

They're rich, creamy and look just like a ripe boob. 

They always love them, even if they don't eat them!

From what I've been told, the female breast is a highly sought after delicacy.

FYI, their other creations are beautiful as well.  This is a good place to swing through to grab something for a birthday or other last minute occasion.
author: Michael O.

description:
All the shops in the Ferry Building have such nice set ups but this one is truly adorable.  The bright pastel jumps out at you and really pulls you in. 

The macarons, the reason I visited, were displayed in separate glass jars and beneath them were the baked goods, which I was told to steer clear from.  

Now the maracon review:
Rose Geranium -- So much buzz generated on CHOW that I bought two right off the bat.  I found them a little flowery for me though.

Pistachio: really, really, really good filling; ate my first one while walking around and went back right after for seconds

Chocolate Lavender: I think i let this sit around for too long; it was a little stale, not as good as it could be texture wise I think. The flavor was decent -- the lavender is subtle and the chocolate reminded me of cocoa powder.

Overall, all had excellent texture and satisfied the sweet tooth.
author: Jun H.

description:
Went to an engagement party today and in addition to the fabulous nibbles they had there, there were about 4 cakes and a tray full of cupcakes from Miette.  Oh my...

I was trying to be good, so I skipped the cakes, but I could not resist the chocolate cupcake.  So cute.  A thick dollop of marshmallow topping.  So moist, so chocolaty, so delicious.

Hubby had the Gingerbread cupcake with a sickly sweet cream cheese topping.  The cake part was FABULOUS, but he had to scrape off some of the topping.  It was good, but it was like a mouthful of straight sugar with a sour kick behind it.  

I just found out that this place is right by my work... danger, danger!
author: Denise M.

description:
mmmm mmmm miette macaroons.  The perfect pick-me-up when you want quality sweets when strolling through the ferry building or enjoying a coffee on the pier.  I sampled a few-- each had immense flavor and the texture was unlike anything else I've had... I only had my credit card and asked if there was a minimum order..the smiling person behind the counter said typically it's $10, but not to worry about it...how surprisingly friendly!  (At $1.50/ small macaroon...it's pretty easy to spend a lot here). At Miette, it's about the quality, not quantity. 

P.S.- loved the chocolate orange macaroons.
author: Sonia S.

description:
I approach the pastry case...

(ethereal voices sing in my head)
AAAAHHHHH aaaaaahhhhhh AAAAAHHHHH aaaaaahhhhh!!!!!!!!

A ray of soft light descended on the few cupcakes left on their rustic little tin trays.  The delicate white creamy frosting glimmered and beckoned to me.  There were three Old Fashioned Chocolate Cupcakes waiting patiently.  

Ack! There are three people at Miette Cakes!!!  Oh no!!!!  Screw manners...Imma gettin' me one o' dem cupcakes!!

I walk confidently and with an air of self-entitlement right up to the pastry case.  Is there a line?  I don't know...I didn't see one, so there must be no line!  

One cupcake please....*drool* No box. Just the cupcake.  

I ran off, away from the Cupcake Deficients back at the store.  I peeled away the paper with the tenderness of Gollum and his ring.  This cupcake was MY Precious.  

And then....I ATE IT!!  

(ethereal voices sing in my head...again)
AAAAHHHHH aaaaaahhhhhh AAAAAHHHHH aaaaaahhhhh!!!!!!!!
author: Jay H.

description:
Update 5/14/08
::start PSA::

Ever wonder what to do when the little lady is in the throes of the monthy madness? Here's a hint: Miette.

A cute package of stuff made from sugar, butter and flour can be an amazing cure-all for the monthy crazies. Trust me. I just got some lavender shortbread, and my psycho hormones were taken down a few notches and I now feel like my true, gentle self.

So when your girl is wild-eyed and lookin' to pick a fight, give her a hug and pop a little gem from Miette into her gop. Then watch the sweet creature you know and love come back to life. ::end PSA::

*************************************************

What's the difference between Pot de Creme & Pudding?

No, really! Do YOU know the difference?
I don't. So here's what I discovered. 

Pot de Creme = rich egg custard

Pudding = a solid mass thickened by using a grain product or other binding agent (egg, suet, blood)

Hmm. Based on these definitions, I have to say that I vote for Pot de Creme!! (sorry pudding!)

Especially if it's chocolate Pot de Creme from Miette.
Not only is it creamy, and dark chocolaty, it's served in a super cute little jar that you can either keep (and use for sea salt, like I do) or return for a refund. Also, let me tell you, the jar's the perfect size for me to fit my finger to make sure I scoop out every last, creamy chocolaty, drop! (nope. no shame here.)

But the Pot de Creme wasn't how I met Miette. 
We were introduced one birthday, where the lavender short bread cookies were elegantly presented to me as a gift. Those lovely little, square-cut morsels are crispy and light and buttery. You know, if I close my eyes and take a deep breath, I can almost smell the butter, the lavender-y goodness... Sadly, they're so amazing that I can't be trusted to keep them in the house, 'cause I'm sure to nibble away at the whole preciously-wrapped-in-cellophane bag in a matter of minutes. (yes, minutes. don't judge) It's embarrassing how little self-control I seem to have when Miette's lavender short bread's in the house!

So why only 4 stars if I'm so wow-ed by Miette? If you must know, I'm totally disappointed in their cupcakes. Were they too dry? Bland? Well? Hard to say. Maybe it wasn't really Miette's fault. I may need to blame Sibby's for this one, and give Miette another chance when Sibby's isn't so fresh in my memory. I'm looking forward to the day when I can say, "Sibby's who?" ...especially since Miette's a few short blocks away...

Until then, I guess I'll just have to keep researching Miette's cupcakes...or distracting myself from the cupcakes with Pot de Creme... or taunting my self-control with lavender short bread!

The things a girl's gotta do in the name of good eats.
author: Tiffinie T.

description: I do think this place is a bit pricy but for the price you pay you know its good ingredients and its organic. The brownies were a bit on the dry side, the meringue was on the creamy side, the Debutante cake was a bit over frosted but its great, the coconut mousse cake was splendid, the Banana Cream tarts are wonderful I really like this place but its only a treat but not all the time.
author: Aurelio L.

description: havent really tried alot except the macaroons and the ice cream sandwiches... macaroons are soooo delicious!!!
author: Isa W.

description: Value proposition isn't helped by them nickel & diming for everything from forks to napkins, etc.
author: Gisele H.

description:
Let me tell you something about cupcakes.  They're delicious.  But not all cupcakes are delicious.  Only some.  

Miette's are among the few, proud cupcakes I would deem delicious.  Because they are delicious.  

The gingerbread cupcake with cream cheese frosting is the most delicious of them all.  

2 other reasons to visit Miette:

1)  They are going to be carrying ice-cream sandwiches made by them and Three Twins Ice Cream (delicious)
2)  You can visit my buddy, and a stone cold fox, Molly (delicious)
author: Tom T.

description:
Mmm, Parisian macarons! And no, that is not a misspelling. You see, Miette's bakers went to Paris and discovered these yummy bites of love, which are completely different from what we know as coconut macaroons. 

France's version is light and chewy, consisting of two crunchy dome shaped halves with a sweet filling inside. I love Miette's pistachio best. I could eat a whole bag of them and still want more. Arghhhh, why do I have to be such a Fatty McFatterson?!?! 

*ahem* Come for the macarons but don't forget to pick up an old fashioned. The boiled marshmallow icing is marshtacular.

ETA: The gingerbread cupcake is my new favorite. Sweet but with the right amount of spice. Give it a try!
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Is it the fact that they are organic that makes them so great, or is it the storybook-perfect decoration and tres Frenchiness of them? I picked up 15 for a birthday party at the Malibu Grand Prix (no, I'm not a pedophile, who doesn't love fast cars and video games?) and they were a huge hit! 

I had called earlier in the day and ordered an assortment, each of which looked like a wee piece of artwork.  They must have felt a little out-of sorts when their pink bakery box house was opened and they were lifted into the dim light of a fumy go-cart track. Surely they were expecting a more posh demise--say at a spoiled kid's birthday party in Sea Cliff or Pacific Heights. "But we're organic and we're $3 each!! Whatever are we doing in this dirty, loud place?!" Just because our little cupcakes went down the hatches in working-class Redwood City, however, it doesn't mean they weren't enjoyed to the fullest! 

Miette, you saved the day, thank you for baking the best for little old us!
author: Gretchen T.

description:
The cupcake I had was mediocre at best. I am a believer in both the frosting AND the cake being great in order to have a great cupcake. Unfortunately, on yesterday's chocolate cupcake with coffee frosting only the former was up to par. The cake was dry and not as flavorful as one would hope. There was a mob of people surrounding the deli case so the employees were understandably impatient, not knowing which people wanted to actually purchase something and which were just gawking. I still felt their barks should be kept to a minimum, though. 

I also tried the hazelnut chocolate macaron. What the hell is a macaron? is it like a macaroon? Because this didn't taste anything like a macaroon. It wasn't horrible and wasn't great. The chocolate orange one my mom ordered was slightly better. 

The dark chocolate rocky road sweets were good but not great. Overall, I was just underwhelmed.
author: Jen S.

description: Yum. Beautiful cakes and cupcakes. Delicious and moist cupcakes. Highly recommend!
author: Sandy A.

description:
This place is scary if you're a guy with any doubts about his metrosexuality.  Come on your own for a prissy little sugar concoction, let's just say it really pushes the gender equation.

Also, poster case of empty calories.

Must have repressed it all because as many times as I've been to the ferry building I never noticed the place, not until the girl I was with said something about cute little macaroons.  I thought that meant I was getting some, I guess it did mean I was getting some.

Cute and fussy and perfect and expensive.  Tasted nice.  The cookie, that is.

This is their only location.
author: Gil S.

description:
Miette is the kind of little place where your eyes brighten up every time you walk by...alot of thought, imagination, and creative energy has certainly made this place stand out.  

But why is it that I have asked well over 5 times to be called and reminded when their miniature pink cake stand arrives and every time I show up and check back in - they seem to take a sort of Mommy Dearest delight in telling me they have just sold the last one.  They have my name AND number in their little organizing cabinet and while it's almost embarrassing that I want something that much to be diligent enough to keep checking in over the course of a YEAR mind you...they should at least make up a story to humor me!!  

I've considered bribing the staff but if it's not meant to be...then why force it? Just another reason to see Paris in the springtime, I say.. 

So...a few extra stars for the pain au chocolate dishes...customer service negative 5 thank you very much.
author: Yelper A.

description:
I'd long coveted a taste of their Old Fashioned Cupcakes and my sister awhile ago told me to try their macaroons. Finding myself finally in front of their counter, I ordered just that: one Old Fashioned Cupcake and two macacroons, hazelnut and chocolate.

The macaroons are apparently Parisian style macaroons. I'll have to take their word for it since I've never been to Paris. In any case, they aren't the macaroons that most Americans are used to, overly sugared and mainly coconut. Miette's rendition is a delicate looking cookie sandwich but don't let the looks fool you -- it's a hardy cookie! I ate the hazelnut one first and immediately regretted that I hadn't bought more. The texture is delightfully chewy, the taste nutty and the hazelnut filling lovely. I ate the chocolate one later and was similarly delighted.

The Old Fashioned Cupcake, however, was a disappointment. It is a gorgeous, gorgeous piece of work. A perfect little cupcake, crowned with an impossibly high, whipped marshmallow-like icing, topped with a little red peanut. I wanted to love it and eat it. It was so perfect looking! So naturally, when I saw it before me, I had to have it. Unfortunately, I knew I wouldn't have the time to savor it properly at the Ferry Building as I had to get back to work so instead, I got it boxed up.

Back at work, I opened the container to savor my cupcake. The icing had fallen to the side (no fault of Miette; I blame BART) but I scooped it out to savor anyway. I took one bite and...

Yuck. Was the cake supposed to be bitter? And was the frosting supposed to be sickeningly sweet? A quick check of the website confirmed that, yes, the cake was supposed to be 'bittersweet' and offset by the frosting. I ate my way through the cupcake, later switching to a fork in hopes that I could effectively offset the bitterness of the cake with the sweetness of the frosting. Nope, it wasn't to be. From first to last, the bitterness of the cake overrode everything. Talk about disappointing! 

I'd go back to Miette for the macaroons but I'll leave the cupcakes for a more unsuspecting soul. The fact that everything is organic is a real plus but the taste... come on, man! If I'm going to pay $3 for a freaking cupcake when I could make a dozen at home for about the same price, you better be damn sure that it's worth my money. And it's not. On the plus side, the store itself is quite cute as are the paper bags. At least I got my $3 worth out of a paper bag I can now tote my lunch in to look cool. *snort* Give me Satura over Miette any day.
author: Michelle N.

description: Miette is like the beautiful cheerleader I dated in high school. So, so pretty on the outside, so dang lovely to look at. But dating her costs a fortune; she makes you take her to the most expensive restaurant in town. And when you get right down to it, something's a little off in the conversation. It's a little too sweet, a little too spicy, a little too fake?? Don't know what it is, but one date was enough. Does that mean the next fella ain't gonna try? Hell no. So you try for yourself, and maybe Miette is just your type. Just wasn't mine.
author: Dom L.

description:
Everything in this store is too cute to eat or touch. If you've never been in here before, try the macaroons first. Otherwise, go with what you're craving. The cupcakes are always a treat if you're giving them to other people--and if you're nice, the shop girls might even tell you the secret to how to eat their cupcakes that are half cake and half frosting. Also, if you haven't been to the dentist in a while, go easy on the caramels. Don't get me wrong, they're delicious! Do not go home without grabbing a couple. But if they hit a cavity, you will be in pain until you can lick all that caramel off that tooth. You've been warned....

Not only are their small snacks delicious, their cakes are as well! If you want something rich and chocolaty, go for the Princess cake or any of the Tomboys. My favorite is the Bumblebee--chocolate filling with yellow cake. Mmmmm!
author: Maureen B.

description: Very, very good. Thought I would try a piece of everything in the cooler box in the front. My son's eyes were as big as sauciers looking at the confecions they had to offer. I am very detail oriented when it comes to macaroons. Flavor, texture, ingredients have to be right or I will make them myself. Felt like i was back in Nice, delicate cookie to go with the coffee across the way. I ate some of the cupcakes as well, they have probably the best carrot cupcake in town. If your fanatical about their sweets their cookbook is probably one of the best books out there, traditional patisserie desserts with their own flair.
author: Shawn L.

description:
First of all, as you approach the case of cakes at Miette, something may strike you as eerily familiar. Perhaps it's because the shop--particularly the cakes and the case that house them--are reminiscent of artist Wayne Theibaud's paintings. This is on purpose, as one of the owners has a background in art and is a huge Wayne Theibaud fan. She wanted to make cakes like the ones in his paintings. 

Conceptually, Miette--a french styled organic patisserie, is extremely clever. Their products are unique, rich and sinful--not to mention organic, too.  The counter staff are always warm & friendly--no attitude here. The lemon tart, after tingling in your mouth, will send you on the biggest sugar rollercoaster you've ever been on. I took one of the chocolate cherry cakes with the white icing to an event and everyone raved about it. Miette is the only place I will buy cakes from now on. Not that much pricier than other bakeries, and worth every penny.
author: N B.

description:
So on our first real browse through the Ferry Building, where should the wife end up but Miette?  Well, those mini-Scharffen Berger cakes are the most insanely rich chocolate confection on the planet, so no surprise there.  But it's also a pretty good Ferry Building starting point for those who aren't quite ready to choose Caspian vs American caviar, real truffles vs truffle oil, or which of the *2* olive oil shops to patronize.  I went with the grapefruit cream cake, which delivers all the tangy-yet-sweet-yet-creamy goodness you could ask for.  But man, $5 for such a small slice...and this without providing a place to sit.

I also couldn't figure out why "Miette" rang such a bell.  I checked the Food Lover's Guide...nope, not in there.  Then I remembered: I believe a certain Ms. W's Yelp photo page used to have a shot of cupcakes whose frosting read "F*** Miette".  Now whatever could that mean?  Aside from "homemade cupcakes are better, cheaper, and more fulfilling", of course.
author: Wes M.

description: My mom and I bought a tiny cupcake, one macaroon, and a bag of lavendar shortbread for about $15.  Then we sat on the pier and had foodgasms while we ate it all.  Worth every penny.  I just hope they'll let me mail-order some macaroons for mom for X-mas.
author: Emily C.

description:
3 sylables:Ma-ca-roons! I tried to the pistacio, hazlenut and rose macaroons and they were bomb! 

I was out on a date in the city and walking the embarcadero building so we stopped to grab a bite and try the cupcake shop....and than we decided to randomly try this little desert that read different flavors at $1.25 ea. Well it was worth it let me tell you because the pistacio macaroons just made my palet scream! 

I must say that the portions of your purchase is not alot but you do get the taste of what you buy though. ; (
author: California R.

description:
I tried a variety of their sweets (they generously donated them to a non-profit I volunteer with for our final night celebration).  Here's my run-down:  

 I LOVED the cheesecake.

I  LOVED the soft caramel with fleur de sel.    

I didn't like the butter cream cupcake frosting (I tend to like sugary frosting more so it's probably a matter of personal preference).  

The carrot cake was quite good.  The cream cheese frosting was delicious!

The lemon curd in the tartlet was superb.  I didn't care for the crust though.

I'm giving it 5 stars because the things I loved, I really LOVED and I appreciate the ability to get a high quality dessert which is not so commonplace in the U.S.
author: Jane L.

description:
I really love Miette for all it's pastel-ie pink-ie cute-sieness, and am not at all ambivalent or bi-polar about its girlieness like I am about Anthropologie.  

When thoughts of smothering oneself with those irresistible $3 Old Fashioned whipped marshmallow frosted cupcakes rouse the heart to flutter, sending your body into joyous convulsions like you're Laura Linney in 'Love Actually' excusing yourself to stifle a scream in the hallway after a longed kiss, you know you got problems.  

Oh, and those square scones are heaven.  I am woman.  Hear me roar.
author: Irene S.

description:
I can't separate my overall state from the actual experience of the place... so for me Miette will always be bittersweet. 

The cupcakes are so INCREDIBLY rich, you probably won't EVER want to eat more than one. I love chocolate more than most, but this is too much. Then again, it wasn't one of those sugary sweet days, so maybe on a different day they would have been perfect.

Definitely try it.
author: Liza P.

description: My wife told me to get some macaroons since I was in the ferry building. I've never really tried them but I must say they are the bomb! I'd rather eat macaroons over a cookie, brownie, or cupcake. The joy of eating a soft cake with what I think is a marshmillowy type of filling. YUM!
author: Keoni U.

description:
5 stars only refer to the chocolate pots. 
I love chocolate pots. 
Chocolate mousse with fresh cream on top.
Worth every, delicious, delectable, delightful lick.
Better than bad sex on a good day.
Mmmmmm....makes me hot just thinkin' about those chocolate pots.
author: Mi M.

description:
Such a cute booth! pretty and pink. 

It may cost a lot but the cuppies are made so perfect looking that it makes you stare at it for awhile before taking a bite. I'd have to say the chocolate with marshmellow frosting was not as moist and fluffy. However, the gingerbread cupcake was delicious!
author: Oanh N.

description:
Best Graham Crackers EVER.
And Lavender short breads....
author: Rachel P.

description:
5/19/07 Updated Review:
i'm bumping miette cakes up by one star, but only because i'm on a nice streak. (i'm also giving up my ufc ratings.) decided to give them another shot, so i ordered a gingerbread cupcake and chocolate madeleine. i made sure to watch the girl this time and i did get the madeleine and not a silly macaron.

i tried the madeleine first and was surprised by its size and flavor. it was at least 150% the size of typical madeleines which makes it closer to being worth $0.75, i guess. further, it didn't taste like a pure chocolate madeleine; i think i detected a hint of orange essence? maybe, but i wouldn't mind going back for another.

the gingerbread cupcake however was a disappointment. the frosting was overly sweet and the cake portion had such an overpowering ginger flavor. sure, that makes it a true gingerbread cupcake, but whoa, flavor overload.

i think i'd only ever come back for the chocolate madeleines and to look at the pretty displays. and oh, the girl this time was much nicer. she saw that i had a brown bag lunch from another place and she offered me a small shopping bag so i'd be able to carry my things more easily. how nice.

7/26/06 Original 2-Star Review:
I'm so dissatisfied I could punch a wall.  I walked all the way over to miette to check out their cupcakes.  But cupcakeS, I did not find.  Their selection of cupcakes was old-fashioned, old-fashioned, or old-fashioned.  Seriously, in the middle of the day during tourist season?  You must be kidding me.  But fine, I bought one anyway since you'd expect not to have any issues with a classic.  And I saw some chocolate madeleines (which I haven't seen anywhere else), so I asked for two.

The cake half of the cupcake was boring.  Tasted mass-produced.  The icing though, which I spread to each bite with a knife, was nice.  It really did taste like marshmallows, but a tad sweet.  Not necessarily a cupcake I'd go back to get.  Seriously, tasted like a Hostess ho ho or a Sheng Kee chocolate roll cake.  Only difference was that it was {buzzword of the 21st century} organic.  And it was so small I reached for my madeleines.

BUT ... when I opened up the bag, what did I find??  Chocolate macarons!  Stupid girl behind the counter with the glazed over eyes who didn't even look at me while I ordered, but instead stared off into nowhere gave me stupid macarons!  I asked for madeleines!!  I figured I'd try it anyway.  Overly sweet and sticky.  Not my kind of dessert/pastry.  I'm giving my second one to someone else.

They're only getting that second star for having a cute store complete with apothecary jars and pink & silver stickers.  I think I'm going to go punch that wall now.

People thought this was: 
Useful  (2)  Funny  (6)  Cool  (1)
author: spiff e.

description: This place is soooo good! A little French dessert store which sells nothing but super delicious cute little treats. Try their rose macaroons - a real disaster.
author: FairMe R.

description: I'm going to keep this short and sweet.  Granted I had only one cupcake from Miette in my lifetime and it was seriously the best cupcake EVER!  10x better than those other guys... what's their name?  Sprinkles?  All of their creations are so cute that you almost don't want to eat them (but when you do you're happy that you did.)  Ginger maple cupcakes ftw!  I'm so sad there isn't a Miette near us.  Boo hoo.
author: Angeline K.

description:
In the last three days, I have been on a hunt for some good macarons for a party. I went to Patisserie Philippe, Paulette, La Boulange, and Miette. Hands down, Miette wins.

It has a great consistency (slightly chewy center), it doesnt look like plastic with bright artificial colors and the flavors are just right (not too intense, not too sweet). It's the closest thing you're going to get to Paris in sf.
author: Nikki D.

description:
This review is only for the macarons.

For $2+ per piece, it is overpriced for its value. I bought one of each of the flavors (5) that were available that day, ate the coffee flavored one immediately and while the flavor is there, I don't think it was the "WOW...so worth every penny!" feeling. It definitely has a light crunch as you take your first bite and falls apart a bit too easily. While it is not one of the worst I've ever had, I won't be shelling out any more cash for  their macarons.
author: J C.

description:
5 stars for their beautifully made treats and cute packaging!! The Scharfen Berger chocolate cake is crazy good ~ not too sweet and melts in your mouth (make sure to eat it at room temp as they will tell you). 

1 star off for their macarons which have good texture but the flavors are lacking ~ tried all the flavors and couldn't tell the difference among them ;P
author: sonia c.

description:
5 stars for the eye candy.  The girl behind the counter looked like a hot version Keira Knightly.

-1 star: dry cupcake
-1 star: $3 per cupcake
-1 star: cupcakes were not really special

Don't make me carry a pink bag, thats not cool.

Very over rated, I guess the whole ferry building is like that.
author: H C.

description:
First of all, after reading everyone else's reviews, I'm kicking myself in the butt for not getting a cupcake!

I got a mini Scharffen Berger cake ($5), an eclair ($4) and a hazelnut macaroon ($1.50). The mini cake and the eclair were yummy, not too sweet and pretty decently sized, but it's still hard to justify the high prices. But what do you expect? It's the Ferry Building.

Anyway, my original plan was to pick up a little something so I could get my parking ticket validated, and I ended up spending $10.50, leaving me with no cash left to pay for parking. :(
author: Amy H.

description:
I've been on the hunt for good macaroons (sandwich version not coconut) ever since my friend brought me some from Laduree in Paris.  Since that beautiful moment, I've eaten a LOT of macaroons and I have to say that the ones at Miette are pretty good!  They don't measure up to Laduree but they adequately fill the void. 

On the whole, they had a nice crisp outside, a little too chewy on the inside and the filling was a bit dull but nice.  my favorites so far are the blood orange and rose.  (i think i've tried all the flavors except hazelnut which sold out that day).
author: Joy O.

description: Meh. I was craving a little sweet snack so I got myself 2 macarons from here. I got pistachio and hazelnut. Both were okay but not worth the $1.75 I paid for each of them. I was hoping to bite into some light and delicate but was disappointed to find that they were too chewy. It was also too sweet and the taste was not to my liking. I've had much better macarons before!
author: Jackie H.

description:
I have to say this place is hit or miss for me. I have been on a sat morning and it has been awesome. I have been in the middle of the week and it has been not so great.
Moral of my story, if I am at the ferry building on a sat, I will stop by. I will not however, go out of my way during the week.
Side note, the cupcake in the box is great for a co-workers b-day.
author: Lisa A.

description:
Wow - all this talk about the macarons and the cupcakes and I have never had either!  
Just something to look forward to, I guess.
But let me tell you about what I have tried at Miette:
Their cookies!  The lemon shortbread is so light and buttery and the lemon flavour is just enough.  The chocolate sable cookies are also crazy good - dark but not bitter. $6/bag
Their fleur de sel caramels!  Holy moly these little wrapped treats are unassuming, dumped in big glass jars on the counter - but they are amazing.  The light caramel is more traditional - really chewy with a great toffee flavour.  The darker caramel is almost like fudge, and it just melts in your mouth,  Just the right amount of salt amidst all that sweet to give your tastebuds a kick. $1.50 each
The ice cream sandwiches!  I almost missed these gems - they are in a small metal cooler at the side of the shop.  Look for them, find them, eat them!  I tried the creme fraiche ice cream on graham cracker cookies.  Wow - when I gave it to my Hubs to taste, I could barely wrestle it away from him.  The creaminess of the ice cream and the most unbelievable graham crackers I have ever tried.  I honestly was not expecting that to be as good as it was. $5
The chocolate pot de creme!  This is my favourite thing ever.  It is so small - microscopic, really - but there is so much chocolatey goodness packed into that little jar.  Its kind of pudding-y and kind of mousse-y and all kinds of yummy. $4 (but you get $1 back for returning the jar).
The prices are a bit high, but for quality that good, I feel bad quibbling.  It certainly never stops me from buying their treats.
Its good thing I live so far away, or I would be fat and bankrupt!
author: Robyn W.

description:
Mmm, cupcakes! I am a dessert FIEND, so I was super excited to get my hands on some Miette treats.
The chocolate cupcake with coffee buttercream was fine, not amazing. The buttercream was a bit less sugary than my taste, but nice. There's more visual appeal than taste appeal.
I am a marshmallow whore, so I pounced on the Old Fashioned Cupcake. Another good, not amazing product. The red candy on top was weird / not delicious. 
The chocolate macaron was fine, locally I prefer Bay Bread's, but ultimately I prefer them when I'm in Paris!
I would eat these treats again if they were offered to me, but I'm not going to go out of my way for them.
author: Melisser E.

description:
What? A dollar fifty for a piece of macaron?  

Got one flavor each anyway (Pistachio, Raspberry, Chocolate, Vanilla, Hazelnut and couple of others I forgot).  I admit it, I am not big fan of macaroons especially with the perceived notion of coconut and it's up to you to take my word for it or not - thankfully, Miette's the French variety.  

But the minute I bit into one of them - pistachio - I understood why the French uses their tongue to kiss. It was simply orgasmic! 

Note:  Even if they are bite-sized, don't put the whole thing in your friggin' mouth. Bite into it...savor the two delicate cookies sandwiching that light, creamy filling and make your dollar fifty last longer.
author: Marco d.

description:
I am absolutely crazy for French macaroons - that perfect confection of crispy exterior, chewy almondy cookie sandwiching a layer of buttercream. There is something so satisfying about the texture and taste - airy, chewy, rich, delicate, nutty, sweet. I brought back a box from Paris last month and have been saving them in my freezer and am down to my last two...and started freaking out like a crack addict who has run out of her stash. 

I felt desperate. I was breaking into a cold sweat. Neeeeeed macaroons. At least, I just need to know that if I have a sudden craving, I have relatively easy access to them.

Was at Hog Island Oyster today (which is a perfect day in and of itself) and stopped by Miette just to look at the pastry case (because everything is just so darn cute. And pink). Then I saw them. Jars full of MACAROONS!!!!
